meanings.definition: To categorize or divide people or groups based on race.
meanings.sent1: In the past, some societies would racialise individuals solely based on their skin color.
meanings.sent2: It is not right to racialise people and treat them differently because of their race.
meanings.sent3: At the silly costume party, they decided to racialise everyone by assigning them colors based on their outfits.
meanings.sent4: The media often racialises crime statistics, leading to biased perceptions of different racial groups.
meanings.sent5: The teacher used a creative exercise to racialise the students into teams based on their favorite colors.

meanings.definition: To attribute characteristics or behaviors to a particular race.
meanings.sent1: Some people racialise intelligence, wrongly believing certain races are smarter than others.
meanings.sent2: It is harmful to racialise negative traits to specific racial groups.
meanings.sent3: In the comedy show, they humorously racialised the ability to dance well to a specific race.
meanings.sent4: The advertisement subtly racialised success by only showing one race achieving their goals.
meanings.sent5: The author's book aimed to racialise bravery as a trait inherent in one particular race.

meanings.definition: To make something about race or racial differences.
meanings.sent1: The politician tried to racialise the debate by bringing up irrelevant racial issues.
meanings.sent2: It is important not to racialise every aspect of a person's identity.
meanings.sent3: During the game, they jokingly racialised the choice of food based on each player's race.
meanings.sent4: The artist's painting subtly racialised the concept of beauty by portraying only one race as attractive.
meanings.sent5: The movie director decided to racialise the storyline by adding unnecessary racial conflicts.
